From the Economist 
“Bolivians head to the polls on Sunday to elect the president and all members of parliament. The leftist incumbent, Evo Morales, is gunning for a fourth term on a platform of economic stability. Thanks to a commodities boom and redistributive policies, annual growth has averaged 5% since he first took office in 2006. The share of the population living on less than $1.90 a day has dropped by two-thirds. But Mr Morales’s popularity is threatened by public anger over his slow response to wildfires in the Bolivian Amazon and his defiance of the constitution and a national referendum vote to run again. The government is spending big bucks on propaganda and freebies—including ovens and tractors—to try to avert a run-off against Carlos Mesa, a former president, on December 15th. The threshold for winning outright in the first round is 40%, with a ten-point lead over the nearest rival. Polls suggest it will be close.“

There is also a lot of public anger towards him because he decided to run for a fourth term even though he lost a referendum on the issue in 2016.

https://www.as-coa.org/articles/poll-tracker-bolivias-2019-presidential-race "Morales first became president of Bolivia in January 2006 just two months after Angela Merkel took the reins in Germany, is already Latin America’s longest continuously serving head of state. Now Morales, 59, and his longstanding Vice President Álvaro García Linera, 56, are on the ballot for a fourth term in 2019 on the Movement toward Socialism (MAS) ticket that would put them in office through 2025. The bid is a controversial one. Under the 2009 constitution, Morales is term-limited. Furthermore, he lost a 2016 referendum that would have allowed him to serve one more term. When he challenged that outcome in November 2017, Bolivia's Constitutional Court ruled that term limits themselves are unconstitutional, opening the door for his 2019 bid. Morales’ best chance of victory is to win the October 20 general election outright. If he fails, his odds in a runoff against former President Carlos Mesa narrow. That said, it’s not a given that supporters of third-place candidate Óscar Ortíz would shift to support Mesa in a second round.
. . .
Morales began his first term in 2006 under Bolivia’s 1967 constitution. Then, the country passed a new Magna Carta in 2009, which “reset” the counting of his terms but still limited the executive to two consecutive five-year terms. He began his first term under the new constitution in 2010 and his second in 2015. Also of note, the 2016 referendum was not a question on indefinite reelection but on allowing a third consecutive term. That said, the Constitutional Court’s ruling said that any term limits were a restriction on human rights, which could allow for him to run indefinitely.

COMMENT:  Morales was the first  indigenous person to be elected president of Bolivia.  He was widely regarded as not corrupt and a champion of the indigenous people.  Early on, he had the guts to refuse USAID $ and kick USAID out because (rightly, as it turned out) he thought that it was trying to encourage a coup (because he is a socialist and wasn't perceived to be sufficiently "anti-drug") and working to undermine the economy to spread discontent.   Over the years there's been complaints that Morales has become as corrupt as any Bolivian politician.

In order to become President of Bolivia one needs to "win 40% of votes with a 10-point lead over the runner-up", or 50% of the vote. The current polling that Morales will at least win the first round vote guaranteeing him a place in the December run off on the 15th December. Freedom House currently gives Bolivia a 4/4 on the question "Was the current head of government or other chief national authority elected through free and fair elections?" but this is in regards to the last election. (https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2018/bolivia) Bolivia is a corrupt country, placing 132 out of 180 on Transparency Internationals rating system (https://www.transparency.org/country/BOL). I think it is therefore 30% likely that corruption will have an impact on the electoral process at some point, either in outright bribery of officials, vote buying or some other form of corruption. I can also see why Morales will win, he is the incumbent and although less popular in recent years he still has a solid base of support from which to mobilise. However, other candidates voters may choose to back Mesa, the countries former president to spite Morales. It will depend on the vote share if Morales fails to win outright on October 20th, and the turnout in terms of which voters who didnt turn out are more likely to vote for if at all.
